title: Final Footnote Faux pas
content:
OK, I have a composition problem. I'm setting the introduction to a volume, and the author has put a footnote as the last item of his text. That page is already 2/3 full, and thus the (long) footnote runs over by 7 lines. Thus the very last page consists of nothing but the 7-line run over. There are only 9 pages (10 with the run over), so I can't realistically run the other pages long without it being obvious.   
   
Any ideas?
author: speter

comments.content:
Use subtly different line spacing than the rest of the book to make the introduction run longer or shorter by just a smidge.   
   
T

I pulled back the line spacing .2pt, and that did the trick. I suppose that won't hurt the grid too much ![:-)](http://web.archive.org/web/20050515203434im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/clipart/happy.gif)   
   
Thanks, Thomas!

How closely is the note tied to the text? If it is really a comment on something about the book, the author can put it as a note to the book as a whole, on a separate page. If it has a specific function, such as 'bibliographical note', that can be given as a title.
